messageBody:
On 02/01/2006 11:41 PM, J. B. Rainsberger apparently said:
> Ben Maurer wrote:
>
> >
> http://ocw.mit.edu/OcwWeb/Electrical-Engineering-and-Computer-Science/6-170Laboratory-in-Software-EngineeringFall2001/LectureNotes/index.htm
> > >
> > > I'd be very interested in your materials, as well, if they're
> publicly
> > > available. Thanks,
> >
> > That's pretty interesting. I like the formal introduction to JUnit.
>
> I noticed that the author points out the danger of using Pluggable
> Selector and reflection in general.
>
> What's up with that? Why do so many people find reflection so dangerous?
I wouldn't say it's dangerous, it's just that it adds more complexity to
the system. Things can break easily after refactorings because
refactorings don't catch the string-based reflexive name of the
method/class/interface.

Reflection in Java is also very slow. If used properly it doesn't
impact the system too much. But that makes the system more brittle
because as a developer I have to *know* that a certain part of the
system uses reflection and therefore I need to tip-toe around it (eg. I
wouldn't want code to call into that part of the system in a tight loop
or something).

I have often found that there are other ways around using reflection in
Java. The Adaptor pattern for instance is a simple way of implementing
the Pluggable Selector. It will respond to refactorings, it doesn't add
much complexity, and it's efficient.
